thread.title: Headrest

title: Headrest
text:
The Michael C. Rockefeller Memorial Collection, Purchase, Nelson A. Rockefeller Gift, 1972 Accession Number: 1978.412.643 Not on view The use of headrests in southern Africa is ancient and has been traced as far back as the twelfth-century archaeological site of Mapungubwe, an urban center along the Limpopo River. There, evidence of gold sheeting believed to have adorned a long-disintegrated wooden headrest has been recovered. While headrests were designed to serve a functional purpose--to support the head while sleeping in order to protect elaborate hairstyles--their intimate connection with their owners is such that they are also seen as precious vehicles for communicating with an ancestral realm. In many instances, such artifacts are buried with their owners along with other personal items. Provenance [Alan Brandt, New York, until 1972]; The Museum of Primitive Art, New York, 1972â€“1978
